title: What is better, a PhD or a doctorate? - Quora

response.answer_text: As several others have already pointed out, a Ph.D. is a doctorate; that’s what the D stands for. But let me try to answer what I’m guessing you were trying to ask: For many (most?) fields, there’s only one “kind” of doctorate available: If you get a doctorate in History, or Mathematics, or English Literature, or Computer Science, it’s going to be a Doctorate of Philosophy, that is, a Ph.D., so the question doesn’t make any sense. But there are some topics where you can get a “practitioner’s doctorate,” e.g. an M.D. or a “researcher’s doctorate,” e.g. a Ph.D. in virology (or some other health-related topic). If that’s what you’re talking about, here’s what I can tell you: You need to talk to talk to the real experts, which means you need to provide enough information for them to self-identify: What specific field(s) and degree(s) are you considering, and what do you want to do with your life?The Ph.D. is fundamentally a research degree. If you want to practice medicine or work in another non-research field where a doctorate is expected, the Ph.D. is probably not going to be appropriate. On the other hand, if you do want to do research, the Ph.D. is exactly what you want.If you’re not sure, and if you’re talking about medicine, I can say this: I see a lot more articles written by M.D.s than I see surgeries done by Ph.D.s.Good luck with everything! Eric.
